title: Do This!
text:
Posted: Friday, October 2, 2015, 3:01 AM Friday-Sunday Catch some ZZZs
You look tired, Philadelphia. It's been a busy week. How about a nap? For the Casper Nap Tour , the mattress-maker has outfitted a trailer with four pods to make a Napmobile, allowing you to get some rest (or, judging from the photo, maybe make a few phone calls). "Businesses should start considering naps as a new way to increase productivity," it says here. "Naps can restore alertness, enhance performance, and reduce mistakes and accidents." Want numbers? They have numbers: 1 in 5 people in Philly (23 percent) would give part of their paid time off for workday naps, 52 percent would give up free coffee for naps at the office, and 74 percent would like their workplace to provide a nap room (we usually just curl up under the desk, but it's rough on the back). The Napmobile will be at the lot at 1950 Sansom St. Times: Noon to 8 p.m. Admission is free; reservations required. Information: www.casper.com/naptour#philadelphia . Friday-Saturday 
Things to come With a little help from her friends, Toshi Reagon performs a work-in-progress concert version of her gospel-rock opera Parable of the Sower , based on Octavia E. Butler's 1993 dystopian sci-fi novel about a religious leader guiding a group of survivors in the ruins of a gated community in Los Angeles. The show goes on at the Annenberg Center, 3680 Walnut St. Times: 8 p.m. Friday, 2 and 8 p.m. Saturday. Tickets: $30. Information: 215-898-3900 or www.annenbergcenter.org . Saturday On the town
The Midtown Village Fall Festival spans seven blocks, chock full of food, drinks, live entertainment, shopping, and more. Events are centered on 13th and Chestnut Streets. Time: Noon to 8 p.m. Admission is free. Information: 215-670-4323 or www.midtownvillagephilly.org . Saturday Smart pop
Best known as the lead singer for seminal post-rock outfit Stereolab, Laetitia Sadier brings her dreamy vocals and low-key, low-fi tunes to Johnny Brenda's, 1201 N. Frankford Ave. Time: 9 p.m. Tickets: $12. Information: 215-739-9684 or www.johnnybrendas.com . Sunday 
Pretty, perky 
That's what George Gobel called her back in the day. Jazz singer Peggy King has been a star since she hit TV screens in the 1950s and is still in there swinging. She performs at Act II Playhouse, 56 E. Butler Ave., Ambler. Time: 7 p.m. Tickets: $20. Information: 215-654-0200 or act2.org.
